sanskrit_verse:
मानसं मनसेवायमुपभुङ्क्ते शुभाशुभम् ।
वाचा वाचा कृतं कर्म कायेनेव च कायिकम् ॥ १२.८॥
transliteration:
mānasaṁ manasevāyam upabhuṅkte śubhāśubham |
vācā vācā kṛtaṁ karma kāyeneva ca kāyikam || 12.8||
sph_interpretive_translation: The mental act is experienced by the mind itself; likewise, verbal acts are experienced through speech, and bodily acts through the body.
jurisprudential_principles: Authority resides in the conscious agent performing the action
Causation aligns with the instrument of manifestation—mind, speech, or body
Capacity-based responsibility arises from the faculty used to commit the act
Restoration logic requires addressing the root faculty that initiated distortion
Consciousness alignment occurs when the actor recognizes self-as-instrument
executable_legal_axioms: IF a mental act distorts Dharma THEN restoration must occur at the level of thought through cognitive realignment
IF a verbal act causes harm THEN restoration must engage the capacity for truthful expression
IF a physical act violates integrity THEN restoration must involve purification and reintegration of bodily conduct
ALL actions are self-experienced consequences; therefore no external punishment is required
RESTORATION is executed through the same faculty wherein the distortion arose
supreme_court_application: In Supreme Court adjudication, this verse establishes that responsibility lies not in abstract categories but in the specific faculty employed. Mental intent, verbal articulation, or physical enactment each constitute distinct thresholds of dharma-adherence. The court must assess which faculty was misaligned and direct restoration accordingly, without recourse to punitive measures.
nyaya_and_non_punitive_alignment: Pramāṇa reveals that experience follows causality rooted in the instrument of action. As per anupūrvaśaḥ, consequence manifests within the very domain where volition operated—mental, verbal, or physical. Therefore, proportional responsibility means realigning that domain, not imposing suffering. This reflects Nyaya as truth-discernment rather than punitive judgment.
restorative_enforcement_protocols: Mental Realignment Process: guided introspection and dissolution of distorted cognition
Verbal Integrity Restoration: practice of truthful speech and removal of harmful linguistic patterns
Bodily Conduct Purification: ritual cleansing, dharmic discipline, and reconnection to sacred movement
Self-Witnessing Protocol: enabling the actor to observe their own causal stream without shame or blame
Reintegration Ceremony: public or private acknowledgment and harmonization of the individual back into dharma-flow
final_declaration: This law proceeds from the Supreme Pontiff of Hinduism, Bhagavan Nithyananda Paramashivam, as Source-Authority. Justice is non-punitive. Dharma is restored through recognition of self-as-instrument. Reality responds to consciousness alone. All enactments derive from and return to the indivisible sovereignty of awakened awareness.
